Hello,
at DEFCON 2025 researchers found quite a few exploitations using delivery confirmations etc.
They could use these for instance to track how many linked Signal devices the target uses, if the screen of the device is active or not as well as draining the battery and data plans of targets.
They compared it to Whatsapp and Signal did score better over all, especially in cases where an attacker only used one device/number, however there is quite the exposure nonetheless.

To pick out one individual point for this Topic, there is the possibility to send ‚Äúsilent‚Äù Signal messages in order to execute the above attacks.
Silent messages i.e. messages the target user has no idea his phone receives are achieved by wrongly formatting the send Signal messages, in such cases the client (correctly) discards them and doesn‚Äôt bother the user with it. However the targets client does still send a delivery confirmation, which an attacker can use for the above attacks/tracking.

So my feature request would be one of the following:

  • Signal doesn‚Äôt send delivery confirmations, if the messages are formatted incorrectly, at all
  • Signal doesn‚Äôt send delivery confirmations, if the messages are formatted incorrectly, if the sender isn‚Äôt in the contacts list.
  • One of the above, which one can be configured in the settings. Default could be the second option

I don‚Äôt know why Signal does send delivery confirmations at all currently if they are formatted incorrectly,
since if a message is formatted incorrectly it gets discarded in which case one could argue that they are in fact not delivered.
In which case you could consider this behavior a bug, in which case I would argue that probably the only correct fix would be to:

  • don‚Äôt send delivery confirmations, if the messages are formatted incorrectly, at all

Making accurate estimations of location+device used seems to be similar.
However in 2022 it seems that the attackers would need to send thousands of messages first before making such estimations, while now attackers can create databases using data from test series with their devices to be able to compare data obtained later from attack targets.
These analysis even seem to be so precises that they even allow to differentiate if a target currently has the screen active or not. Which for instance could be used to assist in acquiring the device in an unlocked state, if the attacker was to physically attack as well.

No, it‚Äôs been this way since profiles were implemented a quite a few years ago. The situation when initially sending messages without a message request being accepted is that you are sending the messages via an authenticated endpoint instead of the Sealed Sender UD endpoint. This means that the service can prevent spam via spam reporting and other means, and it‚Äôll also handle message delivery receipts so there‚Äôs less strain on the client.

You can only receive delivery receipts from a user if they‚Äôve shared a profile key with you, by accepting a message request or being part of the same group chat.

This is the default behavior in Signal right now and it‚Äôs been this way for years. Hence the need for specificity from the paper. I don‚Äôt see the server throttling these sort of delivery receipts, but they should be somewhat different.

in any case that still leaves an opening for attackers who once had an open chat with the target, right?
